name: Central African Music
description: Music of the areas speaking Adamawa-Eastern languages and many Bantu languages, through most of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, all of Gabon, Equatorial Guinea, the islands of São Tomé and Príncipe, Republic of the Congo, most of the Central African Republic, and large parts of Cameroon, Angola, and the northern parts of Zambia.

children.name: Ambasse bey
children.description: African Folk Music developed by the Yabassi people of Cameroon.

children.name: Assiko
children.description: Music and dance of the Bassa people of southern Cameroon, which features a singer accompanied by a guitarist and improvised percussion.

children.name: Banda Music
children.description: Music of the Banda people, a Central African ethnic group mostly residing in the Central African Republic and its neighboring countries.

children.name: Bend-skin
children.description: Most closely linked to the Bamileke people of the Western Province of Cameroon; drums and improvised maracas are the sole instrumentation backing up a vocalist who alternates between rapping and singing.

children.name: Bikutsi
children.description: Developed from the Traditional Folk Music of the Ewondo people in Cameroon, with a name translating as "let's beat the earth" that comes from the stomping dance style that often accompanies it.

children.name: Congolese Rumba
children.description: Blend of Congolese musical elements with Cuban Music (specifically Son cubano and  Rumba cubana) popular between the 1940s and early 1970s.

children.name: Kalindula
children.description: Features multiple rumba-like lead guitars and quick steady basslines, while mixing together elements of other percussion-heavy Zambian styles.

children.name: Kilapanga
children.description: Tradition of the Bakongo people from Angola and Congo that has influenced contemporary styles such as Kuduro.

children.name: Kizomba
children.description: Combines elements of Angolan Semba and French Caribbean Zouk.

children.name: Kuduro
children.description: Angolan music combining traditional Kilapanga and Semba with Techno and House.

children.name: Makossa
children.description: Similar to Soukous, but makes more use of a horn section and bass rhythm.

children.name: Mangambeu
children.description: Celebratory style featuring mbira-like instruments and polyrhythms, from western Cameroon.

children.name: Mbenga-Mbuti Music
children.description: Music of the Mbenga and Mbuti people, Pygmy ethnic groups in Central Africa.

children.name: Mbolé
children.description: Festive, energetic and urban, influenced by Bikutsi, Bend-skin and Makossa; mainly based on hand-clapping and drumming accompanied by rhythmic singing.

children.name: Puxa
children.description: Energetic dance style that combines solid bass lines with subtle melodies and harmonies of São Toméan music.

children.name: Semba
children.description: Style from Angola featuring danceable percussion, lyrics often taking the form of a story, and sometimes accompaniment from a guitar.

children.name: Soukous
children.description: Danceable, guitar-based style from the Congo area.

children.name: Tradi-moderne congolais
children.description: Updates traditional Congolese music with electric instrumentation.

children.name: Twa Music
children.description: Music of the Great Lakes Twa people.

children.name: Zamrock
children.description: Developed in the Copperbelt region of Zambia in the 1970s, characterized by its blend of local sounds with influence from Funk, Hard Rock, and Blues Rock.
